ygData.subject: New Paper & Video: Evolved Electrophysiological Robots
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all, Nick Cheney, Hod Lipson and I are pleased to announce a follow-up paper to our 2013 paper on evolving soft robots encoded by CPPNs. To my knowledge,

Subject: New Paper & Video: Evolved Electrophysiological Robots
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=crdXy17VWsowDApcgU0MiHVQ6lM5t3BPwjwPKx-6fCs1yvkAvjdo
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_6A25E095-4B10-44E8-B1F8-13777B434CE6
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello all,

Nick Cheney, Hod Lipson and I are pleased to announce a follow-=
up paper to our 2013 paper on evolving soft robots encoded by CPPNs. To my =
knowledge, this is the first time that the physical material necessary for =
neural control has been embedded in an evolved, artificial creature. Usuall=
y the neural network control structure is a =93ghost=94 network that receiv=
es inputs from a creature=92s sensors and sends outputs to its muscles, but=
 that neural network itself is not physically instantiated (i.e. it does no=
t take up space and physically interact with the creature=92s body). In thi=
s paper, the control system is embedded into the material itself, which mov=
es us a step closer to truly embodied AI. 

The results include some creatu=
res that are interesting and fun to watch. Please let me know if you have a=
ny questions. Also, do you know of any work where the control structures (n=
eural or otherwise) are physically embedded?

Video: https://www.youtube.co=
m/watch?v=3DHgWQ-gPIvt4
PDF: http://jeffclune.com/publications/2014_CheneyC=
luneLipson_ElectrophysiologicalRobots_ALife.pdf

Cheney N, Clune J, Lipson =
H (2014) Evolved Electrophysiological Soft Robots. Proceedings of the Artif=
icial Life Conference. 

Abstract: The embodied cognition paradigm emphasiz=
es that both bodies and brains combine to produce complex behaviors, in con=
trast to the traditional view that the only seat of intelligence is the bra=
in. Despite recent excitement about embodied cognition, brains and bodies r=
emain thought of, and implemented as, two separate entities that merely int=
erface with one another to carry out their respective roles.  Previous rese=
arch co-evolving bodies and brains has simulated the physics of bodies that=
 collect sensory information and pass that information on to disembodied ne=
ural networks, which then processes that information and return motor comma=
nds. Biological animals, in contrast, produce behavior through physically e=
mbedded control structures and a complex and continuous interplay between n=
eural and mechanical forces. In addition to the electrical pulses flowing t=
hrough the physical wiring of the nervous system, the heart elegantly combi=
nes control with actuation, as the physical properties of the tissue itself=
 (or defects therein) determine the actuation of the organ.  Inspired by th=
ese phenomena from cardiac electrophysiology (the study of the electrical p=
roperties of heart tissue), we introduce electrophysiological robots, whose=
 behavior is dictated by electrical signals flowing though the tissue cells=
 of soft robots.  Here we describe these robots and how they are evolved. V=
ideos and images of these robots reveal lifelike behaviors despite the adde=
d challenge of having physically embedded control structures. We also provi=
de an initial experimental investigation into the impact of different imple=
mentation decisions, such as  alternatives for sensing, actuation, and loca=
tions of central pattern generators. Overall, this paper provides a first s=
tep towards removing the chasm between bodies and brains to encourage furth=
er research into physically realistic embodied cognition. 


Best regards,
=
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeff=
clune@...
jeffclune.com


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professo=
r
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

<html><head><meta http-equiv=3D"Content-Type" content=3D"text/html charset=
=3Dwindows-1252"></head><body style=3D"word-wrap: break-word; -webkit-nbsp-=
mode: space; -webkit-line-break: after-white-space;"><div>Hello all,</div><=
div><br></div><div>Nick Cheney, Hod Lipson and I are pleased to announce a =
follow-up paper to our 2013 paper on evolving soft robots encoded by CPPNs.=
 To my knowledge, this is the first time that the physical material necessa=
ry for neural control has been embedded in an evolved, artificial creature.=
 Usually the neural network control structure is a =93ghost=94 network that=
 receives inputs from a creature=92s sensors and sends outputs to its muscl=
es, but that neural network itself is not physically instantiated (i.e. it =
does not take up space and physically interact with the creature=92s body).=
 In this paper, the control system is embedded into the material itself, wh=
ich moves us a step closer to truly embodied AI. </div><div><br></div>=
<div>The results include some creatures that are interesting and fun to wat=
ch. Please let me know if you have any questions. Also, do you know of any =
work where the control structures (neural or otherwise) are physically embe=
dded?</div><div><br></div><div>Video: <a href=3D"https://www.youtube.c=
om/watch?v=3DHgWQ-gPIvt4">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DHgWQ-gPIvt4</a>=
</div><div>PDF: <a href=3D"http://jeffclune.com/publications/2014_Chen=
eyCluneLipson_ElectrophysiologicalRobots_ALife.pdf">http://jeffclune.com/pu=
blications/2014_CheneyCluneLipson_ElectrophysiologicalRobots_ALife.pdf</a><=
/div><div><br></div><div>Cheney N, Clune J, Lipson H (2014) Evolved Electro=
physiological Soft Robots. Proceedings of the Artificial Life Conference.&n=
bsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Abstract: The embodied cognition paradig=
m emphasizes that both bodies and brains combine to produce complex behavio=
rs, in contrast to the traditional view that the only seat of intelligence =
is the brain. Despite recent excitement about embodied cognition, brai=
ns and bodies remain thought of, and implemented as, two separate entities =
that merely interface with one another to carry out their respective r=
oles.  Previous research co-evolving bodies and brains has simulated t=
he physics of bodies that collect sensory information and pass that informa=
tion on to disembodied neural networks, which then processes that info=
rmation and return motor commands. Biological animals, in contrast, produce=
 behavior through physically embedded control structures and a complex&nbsp=
;and continuous interplay between neural and mechanical forces. In addition=
 to the electrical pulses flowing through the physical wiring of the nervou=
s system, the heart elegantly combines control with actuation, as the =
physical properties of the tissue itself (or defects therein) determine the=
 actuation of the organ.  Inspired by these phenomena from cardiac ele=
ctrophysiology (the study of the electrical properties of heart tissue=
), we introduce <i>electrophysiological robots</i>, whose behavior is =
dictated by electrical signals flowing though the tissue cells of soft robo=
ts.  Here we describe these robots and how they are evolved. Vide=
os and images of these robots reveal lifelike behaviors despite the added c=
hallenge of having physically embedded control structures. We also pro=
vide an initial experimental investigation into the impact of different imp=
lementation decisions, such as  alternatives for sensing, actuation, a=
nd locations of central pattern generators. Overall, this paper provid=
es a first step towards removing the chasm between bodies and brains to enc=
ourage further research into physically realistic embodied cognition. =
<br><div apple-content-edited=3D"true">
